intro: Draba nitida var. praelonga, commonly known as the long-stemmed whitlow grass, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically features slender, hairy stems and basal leaves that are linear to lanceolate in shape. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Due to its hardy nature, it is sometimes cultivated in rock gardens or as a decorative plant in arid landscapes.
